cissp.content: The Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) is the most globally recognized certification in the information security market. CISSP validates an information security professional's deep technical and managerial knowledge and experience to effectively design, engineer, and manage the overall security posture of an organization.

sections.heading: About the Certification
sections.content:
CISSP is an independent information security certification granted by the International Information System Security Certification Consortium, also known as ISC2. It is formally approved by the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) in their Information Assurance Technical (IAT), Managerial (IAM), and System Architect and Engineer (IASAE) categories for their DoDD 8570 certification requirement.

In May 2020, The UK National Academic Recognition Information Centre assessed the CISSP qualification as a Level 7 award, the same level as a master's degree.

sections.heading: The Eight CISSP Domains
sections.content: CISSP covers eight domains of cybersecurity knowledge:

sections.heading: Requirements
list: Minimum of five years cumulative, full-time experience in two or more of the eight domains
A post-secondary degree (bachelor's or master's) may satisfy up to one year of required experience
Pass a rigorous examination of 125-175 multiple choice and advanced innovative questions
Endorsement by an existing ISC2 certified professional
Agree to the ISC2 Code of Ethics

details.Questions: 125-175 multiple choice and advanced innovative questions

cism.content:
Certified Information Security Manager (CISM) affirms your ability to assess risks, implement effective governance, and proactively respond to incidents. CISM is a globally respected credential by ISACA, designed specifically for professionals managing an enterprise's security posture.

Unlike technical certifications that focus on hands-on tools or frameworks, CISM is all about strategy, governance, and leadership in information security. Since its inception in 2002, more than 107,000 people have obtained ISACA's CISM certification.

sections.heading: Four CISM Domains
sections.content: The CISM exam covers four domains:
list: Information Security Governance - Addressing the framework for information security within an organization
Information Risk Management - Identifying and managing information security risks to achieve business objectives
Information Security Program Development and Management - Planning, establishing and managing the capability to respond to and recover from disruptive and destructive information security incidents
Information Security Incident Management - Managing and tackling issues that were not already planned or considered

sections.heading: Requirements
list: Five or more years of CISM professional work experience across at least three of the four CISM domains
Work experience must be gained within the 10-year period preceding the application date
Adhere to ISACA's Code of Professional Ethics
Maintain certification through continuing professional education

details.Domains: Information Security Governance, Information Risk Management, Information Security Program Development and Management, Information Security Incident Management

sections.heading: Continuing Education
list: Minimum of 120 Continuing Professional Development (CPE) hours during a three-year reporting period
Minimum of 20 CPE hours per year

oscp.content:
The Offensive Security Certified Professional (OSCP) is an ethical hacking certification offered by Offensive Security (OffSec) that teaches penetration testing methodologies and the use of tools included with the Kali Linux distribution.

The OSCP is a hands-on penetration testing certification, requiring holders to successfully attack and penetrate various live machines in a safe lab environment. It is considered more technical than other ethical hacking certifications, and is one of the few certifications that requires evidence of practical penetration testing skills.

sections.heading: About the Certification
sections.content: The certification validates practical, hands-on skills in ethical hacking and penetration testing. Successful candidates demonstrate proficiency in:
list: Documenting findings in a real-world environment

sections.heading: Exam Structure

details.Duration: 23 hours and 45 minutes of hands-on hacking
details.Report: 24-hour report submission window following the exam
details.Format: Live lab environment with stand-alone machines and Active Directory sets

sections.content: You are required to write a professional report describing your exploitation process for each target, documenting all steps, commands issued, and console output.

sections.heading: Prerequisites
sections.content: There are no formal educational or work experience prerequisites. However, OffSec recommends:
list: Reasonable Windows and Linux administration experience
Familiarity with basic Bash or Python scripting

sections.heading: Industry Recognition
list: In 2015, UK's CREST began recognizing OSCP as equivalent to their intermediate level qualification CREST Registered Tester (CRT)
Successful completion qualifies for 40 (ISC)2 CPE credits
The OSCP certification has no expiration date and is valid indefinitely

gxpn.content:
The GIAC Exploit Researcher and Advanced Penetration Tester (GXPN) certification validates a practitioner's ability to find and mitigate significant security flaws in systems and networks.

GXPN certification holders have the skills to conduct advanced penetration tests and model the behavior of attackers to improve system security, and the knowledge to demonstrate the business risk associated with these behaviors.

sections.heading: Target Audience
sections.content: The GXPN is ideal for security professionals including:

sections.heading: Skills Tested
sections.content: The exam covers various technical domains:
list: Understanding how routing and traffic control can be influenced to exploit networks
Linux memory organization and management fundamentals, low-level Linux binary execution, and how to leverage this information with shell code
Issues in cryptographic implementations and different ways to exploit those implementations
Building fuzzing grammars and knowing when and how to use them
Creating simple return-oriented chains to achieve execution

sections.heading: Certification Maintenance
list: GIAC certifications are valid for four years
Certification holders must submit 36 CPEs for renewal

sections.heading: Related Training
sections.content: The official SANS course SEC660: Advanced Penetration Testing, Exploit Writing, and Ethical Hacking directly maps to GXPN. The course teaches advanced penetration testing skills to develop custom exploits, perform network attacks, analyze cryptographic implementations, and master advanced exploitation techniques.

gpen.content:
The GIAC Penetration Tester (GPEN) certification validates a practitioner's ability to properly conduct a penetration test, using best practice techniques and methodologies.

GPEN certification holders have the knowledge and skills to conduct exploits and engage in detailed reconnaissance, as well as utilize a process-oriented approach to penetration testing projects.

sections.heading: Target Audience
sections.content: The GPEN certification is designed for:
list: Security personnel who assess networks and systems for vulnerabilities

sections.heading: Skills Tested
list: Comprehensive pen test planning, scoping, and recon
Password attacks and web application testing

sections.heading: Certification Maintenance
list: GIAC certifications are valid for four years
Certification holders must submit 36 CPEs for renewal

sections.heading: Related Training
sections.content: The official SANS course SEC560: Enterprise Penetration Testing directly maps to GPEN. This course provides comprehensive coverage of penetration testing techniques and methodologies used by professional penetration testers.

securityx.content:
SecurityX (formerly CASP+) is an advanced cybersecurity certification for security architects and senior security engineers. It proves you have the skills to design, build, and implement secure solutions across complex environments. You'll also show you can support a resilient enterprise while addressing governance, risk, and compliance needs.

The CASP+ certification is approved by the U.S. DoD, meets the directive 8140/8570.01-M requirements, and complies with ISO 17024 standards.

sections.heading: Four Knowledge Domains
sections.content: The CompTIA SecurityX exam covers four major domains:
list: Security Architecture (29%) - Cloud capabilities, network architecture, security boundaries, zero trust concepts
Security Operations (30%) - Monitoring, data analysis, vulnerabilities, attack surface management, threat hunting
Security Engineering and Cryptography (26%) - Cryptographic use cases and techniques, secure protocols
Governance, Risk, and Compliance (15%) - Risk management, compliance frameworks, security policies

sections.heading: Key Topics
list: Cloud security (CASB, shadow IT detection, shared responsibility model, CI/CD pipeline, container security)
Cryptographic techniques (tokenization, code signing, digital signatures, hashing)

sections.heading: Recommended Experience
list: Minimum of ten years of general hands-on IT experience
At least five years of broad hands-on IT security experience
CASP+ is designed for practitioners, not managers

sections.heading: Certification Renewal
list: Collect at least 75 Continuing Education Units (CEUs) in three years
Or pass the most current version of the SecurityX exam

security-plus.content:
CompTIA Security+ is a global certification that validates the baseline skills necessary to perform core security functions and pursue an IT security career. It establishes the core knowledge required of any cybersecurity role and provides a springboard to intermediate-level cybersecurity jobs.

Security+ is compliant with ISO 17024 standards and approved by the U.S. DoD to meet directive 8140/8570.01-M requirements.

sections.heading: Key Areas Covered
list: Threats, Attacks and Vulnerabilities - Identifying and analyzing malicious code, threat actors, and vulnerability types
Architecture and Design - Implementing secure network architecture concepts and systems design
Implementation - Installing and configuring identity and access management, PKI, and wireless security
Operations and Incident Response - Applying appropriate incident response procedures, security assessment tools, and digital forensics
Governance, Risk, and Compliance - Understanding risk management, compliance frameworks, and security policies

network-plus.content: CompTIA Network+ validates the technical skills needed to securely establish, maintain and troubleshoot the essential networks that businesses rely on. It covers the configuration, management, and troubleshooting of common wired and wireless network devices.

sections.heading: Key Areas Covered
list: Networking Fundamentals - OSI model, network topologies, cabling, and IP addressing
Network Implementations - Routing, switching, wireless technologies, and cloud concepts
Network Operations - Network monitoring, documentation, and business continuity
Network Security - Common threats, vulnerabilities, and hardening techniques
Network Troubleshooting - Methodology and tools for identifying and resolving network issues

sections.heading: Why Network+
list: Covers both wired and wireless networks

a-plus.content: CompTIA A+ is the industry standard for establishing a career in IT. It proves competency as a support technician and validates understanding of hardware, software, networking, and troubleshooting.

sections.heading: Key Areas Covered
list: Hardware - Mobile devices, networking hardware, printers, storage devices
Operating Systems - Windows, macOS, Linux, mobile OS installation and configuration
Software Troubleshooting - Application issues, security software, removal procedures
Networking - TCP/IP, ports and protocols, network hardware
Security - Malware removal, physical security, data destruction
Operational Procedures - Documentation, change management, disaster recovery

sections.heading: Why A+
list: Industry-recognized entry point for IT careers
Required by many employers and government positions

linux-plus.content: CompTIA Linux+ validates the competencies required of an early career Linux system administrator. It covers system configuration, operation, and maintenance, along with troubleshooting and diagnostics.

sections.heading: Key Areas Covered
list: System Configuration - Hardware settings, boot process, kernel modules
System Operation and Maintenance - Software installation, user management, permissions
Linux Troubleshooting and Diagnostics - System logs, performance monitoring
Automation and Scripting - Shell scripting, cron jobs, automation tools

project-plus.content: CompTIA Project+ validates the knowledge and skills required to manage the project lifecycle, ensure appropriate communication, manage resources, manage stakeholders, and maintain documentation throughout the project.

sections.heading: Key Areas Covered
list: Project Basics - Project characteristics, phases, roles, and organizational structures
Project Constraints - Managing scope, schedule, budget, and quality
Communication and Change Management - Stakeholder communication, change control processes
Project Tools and Documentation - Project management tools, documentation best practices
Project Execution - Resource allocation, team management, risk management

sections.heading: Why Project+
list: Does not require extensive project management experience

csis.content: The CompTIA Secure Infrastructure Specialist (CSIS) is a stackable certification that validates expertise in securing IT infrastructure. It is earned by holding active CompTIA A+, Network+, and Security+ certifications.

sections.heading: Component Certifications
list: CompTIA A+ - Hardware and software troubleshooting
CompTIA Network+ - Network design, configuration, and management
CompTIA Security+ - Security fundamentals and best practices

sections.heading: Why CSIS
list: Shows breadth of knowledge across IT domains
Recognized by employers seeking well-rounded IT professionals

clnp.content: The CompTIA Linux Network Professional (CLNP) is a stackable certification that validates expertise in Linux systems and network administration. It is earned by holding active CompTIA Linux+ and Network+ certifications.

sections.heading: Component Certifications
list: CompTIA Linux+ - Linux system administration and management
CompTIA Network+ - Network design, configuration, and troubleshooting

sections.heading: Why CLNP
list: Valuable for DevOps and infrastructure roles
Shows proficiency in enterprise Linux environments

csss.content: The CompTIA Systems Support Specialist (CSSS) is a stackable certification that validates expertise in supporting diverse computing environments. It is earned by holding active CompTIA A+ and Linux+ certifications.

sections.heading: Component Certifications
list: CompTIA A+ - Hardware and software support across platforms

sections.heading: Why CSSS
list: Valuable for help desk and support roles
Shows versatility in diverse IT environments
Recognized for comprehensive technical support expertise

cios.content: The CompTIA IT Operations Specialist (CIOS) is a stackable certification that validates expertise in IT operations and network support. It is earned by holding active CompTIA A+ and Network+ certifications.

sections.heading: Component Certifications
list: CompTIA A+ - Hardware, software, and troubleshooting fundamentals
CompTIA Network+ - Network configuration and management
